content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata>   <idinfo>     <citation>       <citeinfo>         <origin>Department of Commerce (DOC), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), Office for Coastal Management (OCM)</origin>         <origin>NOAA MPA Center</origin>         <origin>Marine Conservation Biology Institute</origin>         <pubdate>20140208</pubdate>         <title>California Ocean Uses Atlas</title>         <pubinfo>           <pubplace>Charleston, SC</pubplace>           <publish>NOAA's Ocean Service, Office for Coastal Management (OCM)</publish>         </pubinfo>         <onlink>http://coast.noaa.gov/arcgis/rest/services/MarineCadastre/CaliforniaOceanUses/MapServer</onlink>         <onlink>http://www.marinecadastre.gov/data/default.aspx</onlink>         <onlink>http://www.coast.noaa.gov</onlink>         <onlink>http://marineprotectedareas.noaa.gov/dataanalysis/atlas_ca/</onlink>         <onlink>ftp://ftp.coast.noaa.gov/pub/MSP/CaliforniaOceanUses.zip</onlink>       </citeinfo>     </citation>     <descript>       <abstract>This dataset is a result of the California Ocean Uses Atlas Project: a collaboration between NOAA's National Marine Protected Areas Center and Marine Conservation Biology Institute. The Project was designed to enhance ocean management through geospatial data on the full range of significant human uses of California's ocean environment from the shoreline to the 200 nm EEZ boundary. Data was gathered from regional ocean experts and users through participatory GIS methods.The California Ocean Uses Atlas Project fills a critical information gap in ocean management by providing an unprecedented, comprehensive, consistent and spatially explicit picture of human uses for management agencies, policy makers and stakeholders interested in sound and equitable ocean governance. Using participatory GIS concepts and applications, the Atlas Project generated spatial data and map products illustrating patterns, intensity, and temporal changes in a wide range of human uses in three broad categories of use: (i) fishing, (ii) non-consumptive, and (iii) industrial activities. The resulting datasets depict patterns of ocean use on a broad scale appropriate for a variety of ocean planning and management needs.</abstract>       <purpose>To support coastal and ocean planning and other activities pursuant to the Energy Policy Act, Coastal Zone Management Act, Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act, National Environmental Policy Act, Rivers and Harbors Act and the Submerged Lands Act.</purpose>     </descript>     <timeperd>       <timeinfo>         <sngdate>           <caldate>2008</caldate>         </sngdate>       </timeinfo> intended for coastal and ocean planning.  Not for navigation.</useconst>     <ptcontac>       <cntinfo>         <cntorgp>           <cntorg>NOAA Office for Coastal Management</cntorg>         </cntorgp>         <cntaddr>           <addrtype>mailing and physical</addrtype>           <address>2234 South Hobson Avenue</address>           <city>Charleston</city>           <state>SC</state>           <postal>29405-2413</postal>         </cntaddr>         <cntvoice>843-740-1202</cntvoice>         <cntemail>coastal.info@noaa.gov</cntemail>       </cntinfo>     </ptcontac>   </idinfo>   <dataqual>     <attracc>       <attraccr>The attributes in this dataset are believed to be accurate.</attraccr>     </attracc>     <logic>These data are believed to be logically consistent.  Geometry is topologically clean.</logic>     <complete>Spatial and attribute properties are believed to be complete, although attribute information has been simplified.  Geometric thresholds from original data are preserved.  No tests have been completed for exhaustiveness.</complete>     <posacc>       <horizpa>         <horizpar>Maximum scale of intended use is 1:80,000.</horizpar>       </horizpa>     </posacc>     <lineage>       <srcinfo>         <srccite>           <citeinfo>             <origin>NOAA Marine Protected Areas Center</origin>             <origin>Marine Conservation Biology Institute</origin>             <pubdate>2010</pubdate>             <title>California Ocean Uses Atlas</title>             <onlink>http://marineprotectedareas.noaa.gov/dataanalysis/atlas_ca/</onlink>           </citeinfo>         </srccite>         <typesrc>online</typesrc>         <srctime>           <timeinfo>             <sngdate>               <caldate>2010</caldate>             </sngdate>           </timeinfo>           <srccurr>publication date</srccurr>         </srctime>         <srccitea>CA_OceanUses_2010</srccitea>         <srccontr>Results from PGIS ocean use workshops.</srccontr>       </srcinfo>       <procstep>         <procdesc> Data gathered from participatory workshops throughout the state of California in 2008-2009 were compiled, cleaned and processed to create representations of ocean use patterns for 27 separate ocean uses occurring in California waters.  Expert input from marine stakeholders provided the raw polygon data for each of the 27 uses and identified both the general use and dominant use areas for each use mapped.  The general use footprint includes all areas in which the use is known to occur with some regularity, regardless of frequency or intensity.  The dominant use areas include areas where the use is most commonly pursued and are defined as areas within the general use footprint that are routinely used by most users most of the time.   The raw data polygons included expert input from various different groups for each of the uses targeted in the project.   The raw polygons were sampled to a common polygon fishnet (1 nm cell size) using polygon in polygon analysis and a count was run to determine how many groups mapped each use as a general use area and a dominant use area.  When compiling the final data, the general use footprint included ALL areas that were mapped as general use by ANY of the groups that mapped that particular use during the workshops. Agreement among the groups was not required for an area to be included as a general use area.  The dominant use areas, however, required agreement by a MAJORITY of the groups that mapped that particular use during the workshops.  Agreement among the groups was required for an area to be included as a dominant use area on the preliminary maps.  Using the count field, dominant use areas were thresholded to include only those cells where the majority ruled.  The final dataset reflects all the uses mapped, identifies each cell as a general use area, dominant use area or no use area.  A Dissolve was then performed on the data including all attributes in order to improve draw time and response. </procdesc>         <procdate>2010</procdate>       </procstep>     </lineage> <overview>       <eaover>Attributes describe the level of use for each use mapped, as either no use, general use or dominant use.  Summary fields for each sector of uses (extractive/fishing, non-consumptive/recreational and industrial/military) show the total count of uses within that sector for both general and dominant use areas.  The All Uses Summary fields show the heat map or count of all the uses mapped as general use or dominant use areas.</eaover>       <eadetcit>NOAA Office for Coastal Management</eadetcit>     </overview>   </eainfo>   <distinfo>     <distrib>       <cntinfo>         <cntorgp>           <cntorg>NOAA Office for Coastal Management</cntorg>         </cntorgp>         <cntaddr>           <addrtype>mailing and physical</addrtype>           <address>2234 South Hobson Avenue</address>           <city>Charleston</city>           <state>SC</state>           <postal>29405-2413</postal>         </cntaddr>         <cntvoice>843-740-1202</cntvoice>         <cntemail>coastal.info@noaa.gov</cntemail>       </cntinfo>     </distrib>     <resdesc>Live Data and Maps</resdesc>     <distliab>NOAA makes no warranties or representations whatsoever regarding the availability, quality, accuracy, content, completeness or suitability for the user's needs of such information.
